u_shaped_ranking.context_window: 4.15   A technical report for OSPAR has highlighted the increasing demand for resources such as copper, cobalt, nickel, lithium, silver, rare earth elements and critical metals, with a doubling of global demand anticipated by 2050-2060 (OSPAR, 2021). The transition to renewable energy, associated with increased energy storage requirements, is a key factor in driving up demand.

u_shaped_ranking.core_sentence: Impacts and measures
u_shaped_ranking.context_window: harmonised reporting, and work to address gaps in knowledge of issues such as impacts on fish and small benthic fauna and long term recovery of the seabed. Impacts and measures 6.1   Reports from ICES (Sutton & Boyd, 2009; ICES, 2016; ICES, 2019a) provide an overview of the impacts of sand and gravel extraction.

u_shaped_ranking.core_sentence: messages included:
u_shaped_ranking.context_window: human activities causing physical disturbance and loss to seabed habitats (ICES, 2019b; ICES, 2019c). Key messages included: 1. assessments of impacts should capture the physical and ecological recovery after cessation of the extraction.

u_shaped_ranking.core_sentence: modern sea bed were exposed, glaciated or crossed by major rivers; or formed under modern marine
u_shaped_ranking.context_window: 2.1   Current extraction of non-living resources in the OSPAR Maritime Area is dominated by sand and gravel. These deposits may be relict or fossil, formed when the sea level was lower than at present and parts of the modern sea bed were exposed, glaciated or crossed by major rivers; or formed under modern marine processes, such as sand banks in the southern North Sea (see e.g. Veligrakis et al, 2010; Bide et al, 2016).
